Description.En:
**Teaching Methods**

A large autonomy is given to the students to organise and achieve their goals.

Students will work in small teams, with each team assigned to a challenge.

Teams will identify and address a challenge/question in the context of their assigned case, such as considering alternate business models or analysing go-to-market scenarios. Students need to ground their reflections by exploring some specific areas: business environment, competition, suppliers, partners, environmental and sustainability issues, etc, both deductively (i.e., through desk research) and inductively (i.e., through field work) as appropriate.

To address their challenge/question, the students will cover the 4 generic steps of an explorative business analysis:

• Identification of the relevant challenge/question,

• Acquisition of applicable concepts/methods/tools,

• Observations (data collection) on a selected part of the case,

• Analysis and interpretation.

Students’ supervision comprises:

• A few group sessions to introduce and detail the assignments, and help students identify the challenges/questions,

• 1-to-many mentoring sessions, where teams will be coached in completing their case study, and progress will be monitored,

• A final oral defence.

Each student will be in charge of a part of the group’s delivery, with specific “roles” defined during the mentoring sessions.

The companies responsible for the case will contribute to supervision, provide data/contacts, participate in the oral defence and/or offer other meeting occasions to ensure rooting of the business assignment in real life.

While the course foresees several (4-5) plenary lectures covering topics that are of general use to all students, most of the time will be dedicated to group mentoring.

**Course Goals and Learning Objectives**

After completion of the I&E Studies course, students should…

• … have the ability to apply, synthesise, and evaluate prior I&E learning within a specific innovation or entrepreneurial project setting and a specific innovation area.

• … have the ability to conduct a business analysis, make decisions and formulate recommendations or justify actions in a real environment.

• … have the ability to choose and apply relevant concepts/methods and/or tools and collect relevant data for conducting a business analysis and making decisions in a real environment.

• … have the ability to produce a professional writing on a business analysis topic.

• … have the ability to apply concepts, methods and tools pertaining to identifying and assessing the impact/value of a technology in an industry, market and/or organisation and the innovation / business opportunities it creates.

• … have the ability to reflect critically on issues related to the development of ICT solutions, and their potential pitfalls due to market and/or social reasons.

• … have developed a sense of "out of the box thinking" and creative approaches to problem solving, even in contexts that would otherwise suggest a technical solution.

• … have the ability to make value and ethical judgements about the development of technological and business solutions.

• … have the ability to work as a team with other students to complement each other's competences and perspectives.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**Evaluation Criteria**

The course is evaluated based on a group oral defence, a written group report, and student individual contributions.

The presentation is delivered in front of a panel composed by the course’s teachers and representatives of the team’s assigned challenge provider. Each presentation should last a maximum of 15 minutes (precise timing will be given during the lectures).

The group report includes both points of content (i.e., what the students were able to perform and their proposed solutions) and of process (i.e., decision-making points, how conclusions were reached, team organization, specific contributions of each team member). The approximate length of the report is 15 pages, and it should be delivered both to the teachers for evaluation and, if requested, to the challenge providers for their interest.

Both the presentation and the group report are evaluated on a 0-100 scale using a grading rubric. The final mark is composed by 1/3rd from the presentation and by 2/3rds from the report, with the presentation being evaluated both by teachers and challenge providers with equal grading weight. This score is then converted to the standard 0-30 Italian scale.

This score is adjusted based on each student’s individual contribution through two bonuses: a 0-2 point bonus based on the quality of the student’s section in the final report, and a 0-2 point bonus based on the student’s performance within their team during the course.

**Books and study materials**

No textbook is required. Reference articles and bibliography will be provided to students by the lecturers, and on a case-by-case basis depending on each student's need.

Commonly-referenced books are:

- Roberto Poli, Working with the Future, 2020

- Rob Fitzpatrick, The Mom Test, 2016

- Joshua Schimel, Writing Science, 2011

**Additional Information**

The course’s Moodle page is hosted on the Teaching UNiTrentoinfrastructure. The link will be provided during the first lecture.

The course is rooted on so-called Challenge-Based Learning (CBL), where teams of
students assist a company in tackling one of their business challenges.
As each challenge has its own specificities, the course develops its content organically, and
different teams might be exposed to different pieces of content. Common topics nonetheless
include business analysis methodologies (e.g., SWOT analysis, PESTLE analysis, scenario
back-casting, ...), business research methods basics (e.g., inductive research design,
designing broad semi-structured interviews, designing surveys, ...), use of data banks (e.g.,
Statista, Our World In Data, World Bank, Eurostat, ...), and more.

Suitable topics for business challenges might include market / business environment
analysis (main forces affecting the business, suppliers, partners, competition, environmental
issues), sustainability and social issues, business modelling, go-to-market strategies, and
more.
All challenges are collected by the course’s teachers in the university innovation ecosystem.

**Prerequisites**

For EIT Digital students: successful completion of all the other I&E courses (I&E basics, ICT Innovation, BDLab, Summer School).

For non-EIT Digital students: successful completion of some introductory courses related to Innovation & Entrepreneurship

**Application Documents**

- CV

- self-declaration of English language level (B2 or above)
